Role of various nano-particles in prevention of fungal decay, mold growth and termite attack in wood, and their effect on weathering properties and water repellency

a b s t r a c t
The resistance of Scots pine wood vacuum-treated with nano-particles of ZnO, B2O3, CuO, TiO2, CeO2, and SnO2 against decay, mold fungi and subterranean termites was evaluated. Weathering and water absorption properties were also studied. Nano-ZnO only was resistant against leaching, while the other compounds leached out from wood specimens at more than 60% release rates. Mold growth in wood specimens was significantly inhibited by treatment with nano-ZnO and nano-B2O3. In Petri dishes, all mold fungi were also inhibited by nano-ZnO and nano-B2O3; however, nano-SnO2 inhibited Trichoderma harzianum growth only. Weight loss from fungal attack by the brown-rot fungus was significantly inhibited by all nano-compounds tested, except for leached specimens of nano-B2O3 treatments. Considerably higher weight losses were obtained in decay resistance tests by the whiterot fungus; only nano-CuO and nano-SnO2 were effective against this fungus. Nano-CuO and nanoB2O3 treatments produced favorable termite resistance in both weathered and unweathered specimens, while nano-ZnO and nano-CeO2 resulted in decreased weight loss in specimens exposed to termites. Nano-ZnO was slightly effective in decreasing water absorption. Exposing untreated wood specimens to artificial weathering resulted in significant changes in the chemical structure as determined by FT-IR analysis; however, weathering effect was somewhat decreased by the incorporation of the nano-compounds.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Nano-particles might be an effective tool for protecting wood against mold, decay and termites. Incorporating such particles into traditional wood protection and preservation techniques produces better penetrability and uniform distribution relative to conventional formulations, as well as high dispersion stability and low viscosity (Blee and Matisons, 2008; Kartal et al., 2009; Clausen et al., 2010, 2011). Thus, nano-particles of copper (Cu), zinc (Zn), boron (B), titanium (Ti), silicon (Si), cerium (Ce), silver (Ag) etc.,
rzi), snkartal@istanbul.edu.tr lg€or), lauri.rautkari@aalto.fi a).
may be important in the development of the next generation wood protection/modification systems (Blee and Matisons, 2008; Kartal et al., 2009). Kartal et al. (2009) reported that Cu, Zn, and B have been important in the development of preservatives that extend the service life of wood against fungi and termites. Blee and Matisons (2008) reviewed the variety of nano-particles, including TiO2, ZnO, SiO2, CeO2, and Ag that have been used in wood modification either in their pure form or in combination with different additives. Several research groups have recently studied the use of nano-andmicronized-preparations of Cu, Zn, and Ag to increase the resistance of wood against fungi and termites (Green and Arango, 2007; Clausen et al., 2010, 2011; N emeth et al., 2012; Akhtari and Nicholas, 2013; Filpo et al., 2013; Lykidis et al., 2013; Mantanis et al., 2014).
In addition to the increased resistance some nano-particles bring against UV radiation, scratch and abrasion, fire properties,
hygroscopicity, and mechanical properties of wood, (Blee and Matisons, 2008; Kartal et al., 2009; Clausen et al., 2010, 2011), nano-particles of Zn-, Ag-, and Ti-oxides have been shown to provide more or less protective activity against algal growth and colonization by mold fungi (Shirakawa et al., 2013). In a study by Kartal et al. (2009), mold fungi were moderately inhibited by nanoZnO treatment with surfactant, but nano-Cu, nano-Zn/nanoeAg mixture, and nano-B did not significantly inhibit mold fungi. Künniger et al. (2014) showed that nano-Ag-containing commercial coatings did not protect wooden test facades against mold, blue stain and algae, due to the low initial silver concentrations in the coating system.
The objective of this study was to evaluate nano-preparations of Zn, B, Ce, Ti and tin (Sn) particles in terms of their capacity to prevent fungal decay and mold growth in wood and on malt-agar growth medium in Petri dishes. Effects of the nano-particles on termite resistance, water repellency and dimensional stability of wood specimens were also determined. Additionally, weathering properties of wood treated with the nano-particles were studied by Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) analyses.

sections.heading: 2.1. Wood specimens
sections.text: Specimens were cut from sapwood portions of Scots pine (Pinus sylvestris L.) lumber. Wood specimens for the mold resistance, leaching, water repellency, and anti-swelling efficiency tests were 20 mm 70 mm 6 mm; those for weathering tests were 135 mm 45 mm 3.5 mm. Specimens for fungal decay and termite resistance tests were prepared from the specimens used in weathering tests. The wood specimens (2e4 growth rings cm 1) were free of knots and visible concentrations of resins, and showed no visible evidence of infection from mold, stain, or wooddegrading fungi. The specimens were conditioned to a moisture content of about 12% in a conditioning room at 20 C ± 2 C and 65% ± 5% relative humidity (RH) for two weeks before preservative treatments.

sections.heading: 2.2. Nano-particle dispersions, solutions and vacuum treatments
sections.text:
The following nano-compounds were tested in this study: nanoZnO (zinc oxide, <100 nm particle size; Sigma Aldrich Chemistry, USA); nano-B2O3 (boron oxide, <30 nm particle size; Düzey Laboratory Chemicals and Appliances, Turkey); nano-TiO2 (titanium (IV) oxide, <25 nm particle size; Sigma Aldrich Chemistry, USA); nanoCeO2 (cerium (VI) oxide, <25 nm particle size; Sigma Aldrich Chemistry, USA); and nano-SnO2 (tin (IV) oxide, <100 nm particle size; Sigma Aldrich Chemistry, USA). In fungal and termite resistance tests, nano-CuO (copper (II) oxide, 23e37 nm particle size; Alfa Aesar, USA) was also tested as a reference chemical.
While dispersions of nano-CuO, nano-TiO2, nano-CeO2 and nano-SnO2 at 1% strength were prepared in ammonia (25%), ethanol (95%) was used for nano-ZnO dispersion at 1% strength. Nano-B2O3 solution at 1% was prepared by distilled water.
Wood specimens were vacuum-treated with the dispersions/ solution of nano-compounds based on the BS EN 113 standard test method (BS EN, 1997) after the first weights of the specimens were recorded. After treatments, the specimens dry-blotted andweighed again to determine uptake retention levels. Retention levels of the nano-compounds by inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectroscopy were then calculated as described below. The specimens were
then re-dried at 60 C ± 2 C for three days.

sections.heading: 2.3. Leaching
sections.text:
Half of the treated specimens were subjected to a 14-day leaching course. The leaching procedure was similar to the AWPA E11 standard method (AWPA, 2012). Specimens were placed into a 250 ml bottle, submerged in distilled water, and subjected to a vacuum to impregnate the blocks with the leaching solution. The sample bottles were subjected to mild agitation for a total of 336 h (14 days); the distilledwater was renewed after 6 h, and at 1-, 2-, 4-, 6-, 8-, 10-, 12-, and 14-day intervals.
All leached and unleached specimens were then equilibrated at 20 C ± 2 C and 65% ± 5% RH for four weeks beforemold resistance tests.

sections.heading: 2.4. ICP analyses
sections.text:
For the ICP analyses, two leached and unleached specimens from each treatment group were ground to pass a US Standard 40- mesh screen (0.420 mm). Ground wood samples were microwavedigested based on the AWPA A7 standard method (AWPA, 2012), with slight modifications. The samples (~200 mg) were weighed into a microwave digestion tube and nitric acid (8 ml) was added. A digestion blank was prepared along with the samples. The digestion tubes were sealed into digestion vessels and placed in a carousel in a microwave oven for a pre-programmed digestion sequence. After the digestion was complete (20 min), DI-water was added to each vessel to bring it up to 100-ml volume.
The digested samples were analyzed using a PerkinElmer ICPOES, according to the AWPA A21 standard method (AWPA, 2012), to determine release and retention percentage of B, Ti, Zn, Ce and Sn after leaching. The percent reduction of B, Ti, Zn, Ce and Sn in the treated and leached wood specimens was calculated based on the amount of the elements in the specimens before leaching.

sections.heading: 2.5. Mold-resistance tests
sections.text: Treated and untreated control specimens were evaluated for resistance to mold fungi according to the ASTM D4445-10 standard method (ASTM, 2010) with slight modifications. Three mold fungi, Aspergillus niger Tiegh., M-370 (HAMBI 1271, MUCL 28820, ATCC 13496), Trichoderma harzianum Rifai, ES 39 (HAMBI 2678) and Penicillium pinophilum Hedgc., CEB 3296.31 (HAMBI 2894, DSM 1944, ATCC 36839, CBS 631.66) were grown and maintained on 2% malt agar at 27 C ± 2 C, and 80% ± 5% RH. The cultures were obtained from HAMBI e The Culture Collection, Department of Food and Environmental Sciences, Division of Microbiology, University of Helsinki, Finland. A mixed spore suspension of the three test fungi were prepared by washing the surface of individual 2- week-old Petri plate cultures with 10e15 ml of sterile DI water. Washings were combined in a spray bottle and diluted to approximately 100 ml with DI water to yield approximately 3 107 spores ml 1. The spray bottle was adjusted to deliver 1-ml inoculum per spray. Specimens were sprayed with 1 ml of mixed mold spore suspension and incubated at 27 C ± 2 C and 80% ± 5% RH for four weeks. Following incubation, specimens were visually rated on a scale of 0e5 with 0 indicating the specimen is completely free of mold growth and 5 indicating the specimen was completely covered (0: no growth, 1: 20%, 2: 40%, 3: 60%, 4: 80%, 5: 100% coverage with mold fungi).

sections.heading: 2.6. Assessment of inhibition of fungal growth
sections.text:
The nano-compounds were also used to determine their ability to inhibit growth of the fungi listed above by inclusion in 2%, w/v (malt extract agar) MEA dishes in vitro. Mutant strain mold fungi cultures (seven days old) incubated on 2% malt extract agar (MEA) plates at 27 C ± 2 C were used for the preparation of inocula. Growth inhibition of the fungi used on 2% agar plates was tested by incorporating the solutions of nanocompounds at varying dilutions prepared with liquid growth medium (2% MEA) (0.001%, 0.01, 0.1%). The growth medium and solutions were autoclaved for 15 min at 121 C and 103.4 kPa (15 psi). The medium was then poured into sterile Petri dishes (50-mm diameter) and left in a conditioning room at 27 C ± 2 C and 80% ± 5% RH. After cooling, the Petri dishes were centrally inoculated with a single plug (5-mm diameter) of each fungus. Controls were set up using Petri dishes containing growth medium only. All tests and controls were replicated three times. All cultures were incubated in a conditioning room at 27 C ± 2 C and 80% ± 5% RH until the growth of fungi in the controls had reached the edge of the Petri dishes. The colony diameter was measured daily, and the percentage mycelia inhibition was calculated according to the following equation:
I (%) ¼ 100 (C e T) / C (1)
where I is the inhibition, C is the colony diameter of mycelium from control Petri dishes, and T is the colony diameter of mycelium from the Petri dishes containing the nano-particle solutions. At an inhibitory ratio greater than 20% the test fungus was considered to be inhibited. The minimal inhibitory concentration (MIC) is the lowest concentration of a chemical compound that inhibits visible growth of a microorganism. Research papers dealing with fungal inhibition by various chemicals mostly use 20% threshold value based on observations if greater than or equal to 20% inhibition is achieved. However, the MIC is generally defined as the amount of a chemical that inhibits relative growth to 20% (80% inhibition) and that chemical is accepted “successful” in terms of “inhibition”. After calculating I (%) values of the nano-compounds tested stated above, the MIC values of the nano-compounds where minimum I value of 20% was obtained was accepted as either 0.001%, or 0.01% or 0.1%.

sections.heading: 2.7. Water absorption, volumetric swell, and water repellency effectiveness
sections.text:
The dimensional stability of treated wood was determined by measuring effectiveness (WRE) values using the water-soaking method.
The dimensions and weight of the oven-dried specimens were measured with a digital caliper that had a precision of ±0.02 mm. The specimens were submerged in distilled water for 24 h at room temperature, and the dimensions were measured again. The WA, VS andWRE values were determined using the following equations.
WA (%) ¼ 100 (M2 e M1) / M1 (2)
where WA is the water absorption, M1 is the weight of the ovendried specimen, and M2 is the weight of the water-saturated specimen.
VS (%) ¼ 100 (V2 e V1) / V1 (3)
where VS is the volumetric swelling, V1 is the volume of the ovendried specimen, and V2 is the volume of the water-saturated specimen.
WRE (%) ¼ 100 (WA1 e WA2) / WA1 (4)
where WRE is the water repellent effectiveness, and WA1 and WA2 are the rates of the water absorption of untreated control and treated wood specimens, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.8. Weathering characteristics of treated wood by xenon weatherometer
sections.text: Wood specimens (135mm 45mm 3.5 mm)were placed in a xenon-arc light exposure apparatus operated according to the ISO 4892-2 (ISO, 2013) standard test method, with borosilicate filters (Xenotest Alphaþ, Atlas Materials Testing Technology, Chicago, IL, USA). The filtered xenon arc radiation is similar to solar radiation, consisting of UV, visible, and IR radiation. The samples were exposed to radiation with water spray with a 2-h cycle, consisting of 108-min radiation exposure followed by a 12-min water spray exposure at a rate of 0.2 l min 1. For the tests, three replicates from each treatment group were exposed for a total of 288 h. The light source was a xenon-arc lamp with borosilicate inner and outer filters; its irradiance was controlled at 0.35 W m 2 at 340 nm. During the light and spray cycles, the black panel temperature (BPT) was 50 C ± 5 C, and RH was 80% ± 5%.

sections.heading: 2.9. FT-IR characterization
sections.text: The IR absorption data were obtained using a PerkinElmer 100 FT-IR Spectrometer combined with an ATR unit (Universal ATR Diamond Zn/Se) at a resolution of 4 cm 1 for 32 scans in the spectral range of 600e4000 cm 1. Dried specimens were milled and passed through a mesh-80 sieve, and analyses were performed on treated and untreated specimens. The spectra were baseline corrected and normalized to the highest peak. FT-IR spectroscopy was improved by an attenuated total reflectance (ATR) unit that provided direct interaction between the measuring beam and the specimen, reflected the attenuated radiation to the spectrometer, and increased the sensitivity of FT-IR-based analyses.

sections.heading: 2.10. Decay performance of specimen before and after weathering process
sections.text:
Weathered and unweathered specimens (10 mm 10mm 3.5 mm) were cut from the original specimens (135 mm 45 mm 3.5 mm) prepared for the weathering tests. Decay performance was determined using the mini-block agar plate test according to Bravery (1978) with some modifications. The miniblock test followed in the sstudy is comparable with the EN 113 standard test (BS EN 1997) to assess fungal decay caused by Basidiomycetes. Specimens were sterilized in an autoclave by steaming, and then placed into Petri dishes inoculated with either the white-rot fungus, Trametes (Corioulus) versicolor (L. ex Fr.) Pilat. (FFPRI 1030), or the brown-rot fungus, Gloeophyllum trabeum (Pers.: Fr.) Murrill (Mad-617-R). Tests to evaluate decay performance of treatedwood generally suggest that the brown-rot fungus G. trabeum and the white-rot fungus Trametes versicolor should be used in screening tests with new formulations (AWPA, 2012). After a 12-week-exposure period at 20 C ± 2 C and 65% ± 5% RH, weight loss that had occurred in the specimens during fungal exposure
were calculated.

sections.heading: 2.11. Termite resistance of specimens before and after weathering process
sections.text: Weathered and unweathered specimens (25 mm 25 mm 3.5 mm) were cut from the original specimens (135 mm 45 mm 3.5 mm) used for the weathering tests. The specimens were exposed to subterranean termites Coptotermes formosanus Shiraki, according to the JIS K 1571 standard method (JIS, 2004). An acrylic cylinder (80 mm in diameter, 60 mm in height), the lower end of which was sealed with a 5-mm-thick hard plaster (GC New Plastone, Dental Stone, GC Dental Industrial Corp., Tokyo, Japan) was used as a container. A test specimenwas placed at the center of the plaster bottom of the test container. A total of 150 worker termites collected from a laboratory colony at the Research Institute for Sustainable Humanosphere (RISH), Kyoto University, Japan, were introduced into each test container, together with 15 termite soldiers. Five wood specimens per treatment were assayed against the termites. The assembled containers were set on damp cotton pads to supply water to the specimens and kept at 28 C ± 2 C and >85% RH in darkness for three weeks. The amount of mass loss due to termite attack was calculated based on the difference between the initial and final oven-dried weights of the specimens (60 C, 3 days) after the debris from the termite attack was removed. Five weathered and unweathered specimens were tested for each treatment group.

sections.heading: 2.12. Statistical analysis
sections.text: Statistical analysis was conducted using the SPSS program in conjunction with analysis of variance (ANOVA). Duncan's multiple range test (DMRT) was used to test statistical significance at a ¼ 0.05 level.

sections.heading: 3.1. Retention level of nano-compounds and leaching of nanocompounds from wood specimens
sections.text:
Retention levels of the nano-compounds in treated wood specimens before and after the 14-day leaching course are given in Table 1. Nano-ZnO was the most resistant against leaching, followed by nano-B2O3. In the other treatments, leaching rates were higher than 80%, and retention levels in those treatments were less than 1 kg m 3. In our previous study (Kartal et al., 2009), nano-Cu with and without surfactant, nano-Zn, and nano-Zn plus Ag with surfactant resisted element release; however, all nano-B2O3 was leached out from the treated wood specimens. Clausen et al. (2010) showed that wood specimens treated with 2.5 and 5% nano-ZnO showed 58e65% Zn release after 12 months of outdoor exposure; however, no change in remaining ZnO retention in treatments with 1% nano-ZnO was
observed. Another study by Clausen et al. (2011) showed less than 4% release from nano-ZnO-treated specimens, while 13e25% of the ZnSO4 leached out from treated wood. Mantanis et al. (2014) studied leaching of some nano-formulations and found that nano-ZnO plus emulsion had a leaching rate of 9%, whereas the same zinc formulations without two emulsions had leaching rates of 38% and 31%, respectively. Likewise, nano-Zn borate plus emulsion considerably resisted leaching compared to the control nano-Zn borate. In the nano-Zn borate systems, 100% and 87% of nano-B2O3 were leached in the test. These studies indicate that nano-ZnO generally shows promising leach resistance compared to water-soluble ZnSO4, and that nano-B2O3 is not resistant against leaching.

sections.heading: 3.2. Water absorption, volumetric swell, and water repellency effectiveness
sections.text: Water absorption (WA), volumetric swell (VS), and water repellency effectiveness (WRE) values are shown in Fig. 1. In nano-compounds treatments, the specimens showed slightly lower WA values than in the untreated control. The lowest WA value was seen in the treatments with nano-ZnO. However, the other specimens showed similar WA rates. Nano-compound treatments also improved VS values compared to control specimens. While nano-ZnO treatments had higher WRE values, nanoB2O3 did not help improve the water repellency properties of treated wood specimens. Clausen et al. (2010) showed that there was nearly a 10% decrease in WA of specimens treated with 1% nano-ZnO a after 12-month weathering process; however, higher ZnO loadings (2.5 and 5% nano-ZnO) had a 32% decrease in WA for 24 h when compared to untreated controls. Soltani et al. (2013) showed that wood specimens treated by nano-ZnO improved dimensional stability and hygroscopicity. Our results for wood specimens treated only with nano-ZnO showed results similar to these previous studies.

sections.heading: 3.3. Fungal decay resistance of wood treated with nano-compounds
sections.text:
Fig. 2 illustrates the weight loss that occurred in the weathered and unweathered specimens exposed to the white-rot fungus, Trametes versicolor, and brown-rot fungus, G. trabeum fungi for 12 weeks. The white-rot fungus caused remarkably more weight loss in the nano-compound-treated wood specimens than the brown-rot fungus. The lowest weight losses were seen in the specimens treated with nano-CuO, nano-SnO2, and nano-B2O3 (unweathered specimens only). Unexpectedly, no inhibition against T. versicolor was found in nano-ZnO treatments. Unweathered specimens with nano-B2O3 showed no weight losses, while leaching resulted in considerably higher weight losses.
All nano-compounds inhibited the brown-rot fungus in decay resistance tests except for weathered specimens treatedwith nanoB2O3, where weight losses were much higher than those in control
specimens. A study by Kartal et al. (2009) showed that nano-Cu, nano-Zn, nano-B, and nano-Ag inhibited the white-rot test fungus (T. versicolor), and that the nano-compoundswere nearly as efficient as their soluble formulations at inhibiting the brown-rot test fungi (G. trabeum and Antrodia sp.). Amore recent study byMantanis et al. (2014) investigated the resistance of wood treated with ZnO, Znborate and CuO-nano-particles against decay fungi and found that mass losses by T. versicolor were notably inhibited by the Zn-based formulations, while Tyromyces palustris was not inhibited by the nano-compounds. Remarkably, nano-Zn-borate plus acrylic emulsion revealed very high resistance to T. versicolor. In a study by Taghiyari et al. (2014), nano-Cu and nano-Ag particles had significant resistance toT. versicolor in particleboard specimens. Filpo et al. (2013) showed that TiO2 nano-particles prevented the growth of white- and brown-rot fungi in treated wood. Another study on TiO2 nano-particles exhibited similar resultswhenwood specimenswere exposed to T. versicolor (Marzbani and Mohammadnia-afrouzi, 2014). However, the decay resistance test results in our study were not in accordance with these previous studies in terms of the low resistance of the nano-compounds against white-rot fungus other than nano-CuO and nano-SnO2.

sections.heading: 3.4. Mold resistance of wood treated with the nano-compounds and inhibition of fungal growth
sections.text:
In mold resistance tests, the lowest mold rating was obtained in the specimens treated with nano-ZnO and nano-B2O3 (Fig. 3). No other treatments enhanced mold resistance of wood specimens, and all specimens showed mold ratings as high as untreated controls at the end of the 4-week fungal exposure. These results suggest that 1% concentration levels of nano-CeO2, nano-TiO2, and nano-SnO2 are not enough to protect wood against mold growth on surfaces, and that higher loadings of these compounds might be needed for better performance. Similarly, in mold inhibition tests in Petri dishes, the highest percentages of mold inhibition were obtained for nano-ZnO and nano-B2O3 at 0.1% concentration (Fig. 4). On the other hand, nano-SnO2 inhibited T. harzianum growth in Petri dishes at around 40% at the highest concentration level. NanoTiO2 was the least effective compound in terms of mold inhibition, and none of the nano-compounds were able to inhibit growth completely. Kartal et al. (2009) showed that nano-CuO, nano-ZnO, nano-B2O3, and nano-Ag (with/without surfactant) failed to
provide sufficient protection against mold growth on wood surfaces. Chen et al. (2009) studied the antifungal activity of two different types of nano-phase TiO2 photocatalytic reaction against mold fungus, A. niger, for wet wood boards during a period of several weeks and found that TiO2-coated film in the presence of UVA irradiation had antifungal ability and no visible growth on the wood specimens during the photo-process. Mantanis et al. (2014) studied the resistance of wood treated with ZnO, Zn-borate, and CuO-nano-particles against mold fungi. Results showed that the mold fungi were slightly inhibited only by nano-Zn-borate treatments.

sections.heading: 3.5. Termite resistance of wood treated with the nano-compounds
sections.text:
Termite resistance test results are summarized in Table 2. Consumption of wood specimens by termites was determined based on weight loss following a standardized termite bioassay, and mortality was ascertained by counting dead termites each week of the termite test. Highest weight loss was seen in sugi control wood specimens, followed by untreated pine wood specimens. The least weight loss was observed in specimens treated with nano-SnO2 for unweathered specimens; weathering caused considerably higher weight wood consumption by termites. For both weathered and unweathered specimens treated with nano-CuO and nano-B2O3, wood consumption was less than 5%. In nano-particle treatments, on the other hand, the highest weight losses occurred in specimens treated with nano-TiO2.
All treatments except for nano-B2O3 had low termite mortality, ranging from 5.45% to 15.15%, indicating the non-palatability or repellency of treatments. All termites were dead in the first week of the termite test with the nano-B2O3 treatments. Green and Arango (2007) reported that 0.5% nano-zinc (with and without silver) inhibited termite feeding and caused 70e76% termite mortality; however, nano-copper was not effective against subterranean termites. Kartal et al. (2009) found that nano-boron and nano-zinc with surfactant resulted in 100% and 31% mortality, respectively, and nano-zinc inhibited termite feeding. Nano-copper treatments, however, were less effective against termites. In our previous study (Clausen et al., 2011), eastern subterranean termites (Reticulitermes flavipes) resulted in weight loss of less than 10% of leached nanoZnO-treated wood with 93e100% mortality in all treatment concentrations (1, 2, and 5%). Mantanis et al. (2014) showed that
leached specimens treated with nano-zinc borate, with or without acrylic emulsion, inhibited termite feeding with mass losses between 5.2 and 5.4%, while nano-copper-based treatments were much less effective against subterranean termites, Coptotermes formosanus. In a recent study, however, nano-CuO inhibited termite attack in both leached and unleached specimens, and nano-ZnO was less effective against termite feeding than nano-CuO and nano-B2O3 treatments.

sections.heading: 3.6. FT-IR evaluations of the specimens
sections.text:
The IR spectra of unweathered and weathered untreated control
wood specimens are shown in Fig. 5, and the observed IR bands are presented in Table 3 (Harrington et al., 1964; Faix et al., 1991; Pandey, 1999; Hon and Shiraishi, 2001; Pandey and Pitman, 2003).
It is clear that the 288-h weathering process caused significant changes to the wood surface in terms of the main polymers. As may be seen in Fig. 5, the hemicelluloses were substantially reduced, and the lignin peaks disappeared. The band at 1735 cm 1, indicating an unconjugated C]O stretch in xylan, decreased sharply and shifted at 1721 cm 1, due to the degradation of acetyl groups (Temiz et al., 2006; Lionetto et al., 2012). In addition, the band at 1453 cm 1 characteristic of CH deformation in lignin and carbohydrates disappeared, while the next band at 1421 cm 1 appeared
to maintain its location. On the other hand, the characteristic bands for cellulose at 1106 cm 1 and 1046 cm 1 had small shoulders in the control specimen, but became remarkable peaks after weathering, and the intensity of the band at 1157 cm 1 assigned to the CeOeC vibration in cellulose increased (Fig. 5). The IR bands at 1026 cm 1 and 895 cm 1 representing the presence of cellulose seemed unchanged, indicating that cellulose was the polymer in wood most resistant to the weathering effect.
Fig. 6 compares untreated and nano-compounds-treated wood specimens after weathering. After 288 h of weathering, the intensity of the band at 2921 cm 1 assigned to CH stretching methyl and methylene groups decreased and shifted at 2886 cm 1, and the next spectrum band also assigned to CeH vibration stretching at 2850 cm 1 decreased significantly (Fig. 6). In addition, lignin bands observed in control specimen at 1595 cm 1 and 1509 cm 1 for aromatic skeletal vibrations completely disappeared after weathering, as may be seen in Fig. 5. It is known that the effect of weathering begins in the wood surface, causing a decrease in lignin content, as well as the formation of carbonyl, carboxyl, and hydroperoxide groups, quinine and conjugated double bonds (Hon and Shiraishi, 2001).
Moreover, the IR band at 1646 cm 1, which is attributed to the HOH deformation vibration of absorbed water and conjugated carbonyl groups, mainly originating from the lignin, shifted at
1630 cm 1 after weathering, and it is thought that new carbonyl groups occurred in the wood matrix (Fig. 7). After weathering, another new band was detected at 1198 cm 1 for the nanocompounds except for nano-SnO2, which was not observed in control specimen (Fig. 7). It was clear that lignin was the most affected component and was more altered by the UV effect than the hemicelluloses. While the bands characteristic for lignin disappeared, the bands for cellulose and hemicelluloses survived, although they shifted and became less intense.
The application of nano-ZnO, nano-CuO, nano-TiO2, nanoB2O3, nano-CeO2, and nano-SnO2 contributed very little to the prevention of weathering on the surface characteristics of treated wood. The band at 3333 cm 1 was attributed to OeH stretching of bonded hydroxyl groups, and the intensity of the band (from 0.0884 to 0.0464) was decreased 48% by the weathering effect (Fig. 6). This may have been due to the degradation of the hemicelluloses after weathering, which contained free OH groups. The addition of nano-compounds caused diverse changes in the intensities of this spectrum band. The magnitude of the peaks decreased for the band at 2921 cm 1 from the highest to lowest in the following order: unweathered control, weathered nano-ZnO, weathered nano-CuO, weathered nano-TiO2, weathered nano-B2O3, weathered nano-CeO2, and weathered nanoSnO2. sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
We evaluated the nano-particle forms of some metal oxides intended for wood protection in terms of their leachability and biological resistance to decay, mold fungi, and termites. NanoZnO showed favorable leach resistance compared to the other nano-compounds tested. Nano-CuO and nano-SnO2 inhibited
fungal decay by T. versicolor in both weathered and unweathered specimens; however, all nano-compounds were effective into preventing decay by G. trabeum except for nano-B2O3-treated and weathered specimens. Nano-CuO and nano-B2O3 also inhibited termite feeding. On the other hand, nano-ZnO and nano-CeO2 treatments caused only moderate termite resistance. In mold resistance tests, nano-ZnO and nano-B2O3 in this study effectively inhibited mold growth. No contribution to weathering was seen when wood specimens were treated with the nanocompounds.

metadata.abstractText: The resistance of Scots pine wood vacuum-treated with nano-particles of ZnO, B2O3, CuO, TiO2, CeO2, and SnO2 against decay, mold fungi and subterranean termites was evaluated. Weathering and water absorption properties were also studied. Nano-ZnO only was resistant against leaching, while the other compounds leached out from wood specimens at more than 60% release rates. Mold growth in wood specimens was significantly inhibited by treatment with nano-ZnO and nano-B2O3. In Petri dishes, all mold fungi were also inhibited by nano-ZnO and nano-B2O3; however, nano-SnO2 inhibited Trichoderma harzianum growth only. Weight loss from fungal attack by the brown-rot fungus was significantly inhibited by all nano-compounds tested, except for leached specimens of nano-B2O3 treatments. Considerably higher weight losses were obtained in decay resistance tests by the whiterot fungus; only nano-CuO and nano-SnO2 were effective against this fungus. Nano-CuO and nanoB2O3 treatments produced favorable termite resistance in both weathered and unweathered specimens, while nano-ZnO and nano-CeO2 resulted in decreased weight loss in specimens exposed to termites. Nano-ZnO was slightly effective in decreasing water absorption. Exposing untreated wood specimens to artificial weathering resulted in significant changes in the chemical structure as determined by FT-IR analysis; however, weathering effect was somewhat decreased by the incorporation of the nano-compounds. © 2015 Elsevier Ltd.
